document.title: Direct Adaptive Controller for Uncertain MIMO Dynamic Systems with Time-varying Delay and Dead-zone Inputs \thanksreffootnoteinfo

creator.contact: 1College of Automation Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China, 510006.
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Cambridge, MA, USA, 02139.
3State Key Laboratory of Synthetical Automation for Process Industries, Northeastern University, China, 110189.
4School of Automation and Electrical Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, China, 110083.

abstract.name: Abstract
abstract.p: This paper presents an adaptive tracking control method for a class of nonlinearly parameterized MIMO dynamic systems with time-varying delay and unknown nonlinear dead-zone inputs. A new high dimensional integral Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional is introduced for the adaptive controller to guarantee global stability of the considered systems and also ensure convergence of the tracking errors to the origin. The proposed method provides an alternative to existing methods used for MIMO time-delay systems with dead-zone nonlinearities.

para.p: footnoteinfo]This paper was not presented at any IFAC meeting. E-mail addresses: zjli@ieee.org (Zhijun Li), junfu@mit.edu (Jun Fu), cys@ustb.edu.cn (Changyin Sun).This work was supported by the Natural Science Foundation of China under Grants 61174045, 61473063 and 61125306, the Program for New Century Excellent Talents in University No. NCET-12-0195, Guangzhou Research Collaborative Innovation Projects (No. 2014Y2-00507), and National High-Tech Research and Development Program of China (863 Program) (Grant No. 2015AA042303).
daptive control, MIMO systems, Time-varying delay, Unknown dead-zones

In the past decades, control of multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) practical systems has attracted a great deal of attention, such as flying robots ((1)), biped robots ((2)) and underwater vehicle ((3)). To characterize certain non-sensitivity for small control inputs of these MIMO systems, dead-zone nonlinearities have to be considered otherwise it can severely limit system performances, even leading to instability. To handle dead-zone nonlinearities, many control approaches have been developed in the literature such as ((9)) and ((5)). On the other hand, time-delay usually can be encountered in these MIMO systems, dealt with by many authors, e.g., ((3)) and references therein. Time-delay, like the dead-zone nonlinearities, can also degrade the system performances or lead to instability if ignored during the course of controller designs. Given the effects of the dead-zone and time-delay, this paper considers a class of nonlinearly parameterized MIMO dynamic systems where time-varying delay and unknown nonlinear dead-zone are simultaneously taken into accounts.

To the considered problem in this paper, the most relevant papers are ((9)), ((5)), ((6)), ((11)) and ((4)). In ((9)), an adaptive neural control was proposed for a class of uncertain MIMO nonlinear state time-varying delay systems with unknown nonlinear dead-zones and gain signs, however, it only guarantees semiglobal stability of the closed-loop system. Both ((5)) and ((6)) used the backstepping techniques to construct the controllers. However, the backstepping procedure is computationally time-consuming due to the computation of many virtual controllers for the MIMO systems. The authors of ((11)) proposed a decentralized controller for large-scale systems with time-delay and dead-zone nonlinearities. However, in ((11)), the time-delay is constant and the parameters of the dead-zone are known. In ((4)) the authors constructed a novel Lyapunov function and then designed a smooth adaptive state feedback controller for the time-delay system with dead-zone input. However, linear dead-zone was considered and the tracking error can converge only within an adjustable region. Thus one may wonder if it is possible to propose a new control method completely different from those existing ones to overcome these disadvantages mentioned above? This paper provides an affirmative answer by introducing a new high dimensional integral functional as a Lyapunov-Krasovskii function of the closed-loop systems.

From the motivation above and following our previous work ((12)), this paper introduces a new high dimensional integral Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional for a class of nonlinearly parameterized MIMO systems with time-varying delay in states and unknown nonlinear dead-zones to achieve its tracking control.

Compared to the existing results, the main contributions of this paper are: i) By proposing a Lyapunov-based adaptive control structure, neither cancelation of the coupling matrix during linearizing the system nor conventional backstepping techniques is needed; ii) By introducing a new high-dimensional integral Lyapunov function in the control design, the process of controller design is simplified, i.e., it is unnecessary to calculate the inverse of the unknown control gain matrix; iii) By the construction of the Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional, the unknown time-varying delay in the upper bounding function of the Lyapunov functional derivative can be easily eliminated; iv) The developed control strategy is applied to a 2-DOF robotic manipulator system and the comparative simulation studies demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method.
Consider the following uncertain MIMO nonlinear time-delay system with dead-zone nonlinearities

Math.text: cases@(Array[[(dot@(x)) _ i = x _ (i + 1), ], [(dot@(x)) _ n = B ^ (- 1) * x * delimited-[]@(F * x * (t - tau * t) + D * t + u), ], [y = x _ 1, ]])
cases@(Array[[(dot@(x)) _ i = x _ (i + 1), ], [(dot@(x)) _ n = B ^ (- 1) * x * delimited-[]@(F * x * (t - tau * t) + D * t + u), ], [y = x _ 1, ]])

para.p: where x=[x1T,x2T,…,xnT]T∈R⁢nm is the state vector, xi=[x⁢i1,x⁢i2,…,x⁢im]T∈Rm and y(-i1)=xi(i=1,2,…,n); the nonlinear function ∈⁢F(⁢x(-t⁢τ(t)))Rm; ∈⁢B(x)R×mm are unknown continuous bounded function matrix; and the nonlinear function vector D(t)=[d1,d2.…,dm]T denotes the external disturbance. u=[u1,u2,…,um]T∈Rm is the output of the dead-zone control input and satisfies that if ≥vib⁢ir, =ui⁢g⁢ir(vi); if b⁢il<vi<b⁢ir, =ui0; if ≤vib⁢il, =ui⁢g⁢il(vi), where ∈viR is the input to the ith dead-zone, and b⁢il and b⁢ir are the unknown parameters of the ith dead-zone. In the paper, we consider the dimension of y and xi(i=1,2,…,n) are equal, therefore, =yx1 holds.

The control objective is to find a control input =V[v1,v2,…,vm]T such that the output of the system tracks the desired trajectory ∈ydRm , while all the signals of the closed-loop system are globally bounded.

p.text: The introduction of ⁢B(x) is for the physical meaning of mechanical system, which can represent to the inertia matrix for the system.

The matrix ∈⁢B(x)R×mm is known to be either uniformly symmetric positive definite or uniformly symmetric negative definite for all ∈xRn, and have m eigenvalues. Therefore, for the positive definite case, we have the following inequalities

Math.text: formulae@(lambda _ (m * i * n) * B * (norm@(x)) ^ 2 less= x ^ T * B * x less= lambda _ (m * a * x) * B * (norm@(x)) ^ 2, for-all@(x) element-of R ^ n)
formulae@(lambda _ (m * i * n) * B * (norm@(x)) ^ 2 less= x ^ T * B * x less= lambda _ (m * a * x) * B * (norm@(x)) ^ 2, for-all@(x) element-of R ^ n)

p.text: where ⁢λ⁢min(B) and ⁢λ⁢max(B) denote the minimum and maximum eigenvalues of B, respectively ((15)), ((16)).

((9)) The dead-zone outputs u1,…,um are not available and the dead-zone parameters ⁢b⁢ir and b⁢il are unknown constants, but their signs are known, i.e., b⁢ir>⁢0 and b⁢il<0,=i1,2,…,m. The growth of the ith dead-zone’s left and right functions, ⁢g⁢il(vi) and ⁢g⁢ir(vi), are smooth, and there exist unknown positive constants k⁢il0,k⁢il1,k⁢ir0 and k⁢ir1 such that

Math.text: formulae@(0 less k _ (i * l * 0) less= (g _ (i * l)) ^ ^prime * v _ i less= k _ (i * l * 1), for-all@(v _ i) element-of open-closed-interval@(- infinity, b _ (i * l)))
0 less k _ (i * l * 0)
formulae@((g _ (i * l)) ^ ^prime * v _ i less= k _ (i * l * 1), for-all@(v _ i) element-of open-closed-interval@(- infinity, b _ (i * l)))
formulae@(0 less k _ (i * r * 0) less= (g _ (i * r)) ^ ^prime * v _ i less= k _ (i * r * 1), for-all@(v _ i) element-of closed-open-interval@(b _ (i * r), + infinity))
0 less k _ (i * r * 0)
formulae@((g _ (i * r)) ^ ^prime * v _ i less= k _ (i * r * 1), for-all@(v _ i) element-of closed-open-interval@(b _ (i * r), + infinity))

p.text: where ≤β⁢i0⁢min{k⁢il0,k⁢ir0} is a known positive constant, and =⁢g⁢il′(vi)⁢/⁢dg⁢il(z)dz=zvi and =⁢g⁢ir′(vi)⁢/⁢dg⁢ir(z)dz=zvi.
((8)) The unknown state time-varying delays ⁢τi(t) satisfy ⁢˙τi(t)≤¯τ⁢max<1, =i1,⋯,m, with the known constants ¯τ⁢max.

para.p: We know that there exist ((9)), ∈⁢ξ⁢il(vi)(-∞,b⁢ir) and ∈⁢ξ⁢ir(vi)(b⁢il,+∞) such that

Math.text: formulae@(g _ (i * l) * v _ i = g _ (i * l) * v _ i - g _ (i * l) * b _ (i * l) = (g _ (i * l)) ^ ^prime * xi _ (i * l) * v _ i * (v _ i - b _ (i * l)), [for] * xi _ (i * l) * v _ i element-of open-interval@(v _ i, b _ (i * l)) * [ or ] * open-interval@(b _ (i * l), v _ i))
g _ (i * l) * v _ i
g _ (i * l) * v _ i - g _ (i * l) * b _ (i * l) = (g _ (i * l)) ^ ^prime * xi _ (i * l) * v _ i * (v _ i - b _ (i * l))
[for] * xi _ (i * l) * v _ i element-of open-interval@(v _ i, b _ (i * l)) * [ or ] * open-interval@(b _ (i * l), v _ i)

formulae@(g _ (i * r) * v _ i = g _ (i * r) * v _ i - g _ (i * r) * b _ (i * r) = (g _ (i * r)) ^ ^prime * xi _ (i * r) * v _ i * (v _ i - b _ (i * r)), [for] * xi _ (i * r) * v _ i element-of open-interval@(v _ i, b _ (i * r)) * [ or ] * open-interval@(b _ (i * r), v _ i))
g _ (i * r) * v _ i
g _ (i * r) * v _ i - g _ (i * r) * b _ (i * r) = (g _ (i * r)) ^ ^prime * xi _ (i * r) * v _ i * (v _ i - b _ (i * r))
[for] * xi _ (i * r) * v _ i element-of open-interval@(v _ i, b _ (i * r)) * [ or ] * open-interval@(b _ (i * r), v _ i)

para.p: Define vectors =⁢Φi(t)[⁢φ⁢ir(t),⁢φ⁢il(t)]T and =⁢Ki(t)[⁢g⁢ir′(⁢ξ⁢ir(⁢vi(t))),⁢g⁢il′(⁢ξ⁢il(⁢vi(t)))]T with

Math.text: varphi _ (i * r) * t = cases@(Array[[1, [if], v _ i * t > b _ (i * l)], [0, [if], v _ i * t less= b _ (i * l)]]) * varphi _ (i * l) * t = cases@(Array[[1, [if], v _ i * t less b _ (i * r)], [0, [if], v _ i * t >= b _ (i * r)]])

para.p: Based on Assumption 2.1, the dead-zone control input can be rewritten as follows

Math.text: u _ i = (K _ i) ^ T * t * Phi _ i * t * v _ i + xi _ i * v _ i

para.p: where

Math.text: xi _ i * v _ i = cases@(Array[[- (g _ (i * r)) ^ ^prime * xi _ (i * r) * v _ i * b _ (i * r), [if], v _ i >= b _ (i * r)], [[-[g⁢il′(ξ⁢il(vi))], , ], [[+g⁢ir′(ξ⁢ir(vi))]vi,], [if], b _ (i * l) less v _ i less b _ (i * r)], [- (g _ (i * l)) ^ ^prime * xi _ (i * l) * v _ i * b _ (i * l), [if], v _ i less= b _ (i * l)]])

para.p: and ≤|⁢ξi(vi)|pi∗, where pi∗ is an unknown positive constant with =pi*⁢(+k⁢ir1k⁢kl1)max{b⁢ir,-b⁢il}. Therefore, we have

Math.text: u = K ^ T * Phi * V + Xi
u = K ^ T * Phi * V + Xi

para.p: where =K⁢diag[⁢Ki(t)], =Φ⁢diag[⁢Φi(t)] and =Ξ[⁢ξ1(v1),…,⁢ξm(vm)]T.
Let ∈⁢Bd(x)R×mm be a diagonal matrix with diagonal elements b⁢dii≠0(i=1,2,…,m), then, there exists an unknown matrix ΔB such that =⁢B(x)+⁢Bd(x)ΔB is satisfied. We can rewrite (1) as

Math.text: B * x * (dot@(x)) _ n = F * x * (t - tau * t) + D * t + u
B * x * (dot@(x)) _ n = F * x * (t - tau * t) + D * t + u

para.p: Substituting (9) and ⁢B(x) into (10), we can obtain

Math.text: B _ d * x * (dot@(x)) _ n = F * x * (t - tau * t) + K ^ T * Phi * V + Delta _ P
B _ d * x * (dot@(x)) _ n = F * x * (t - tau * t) + K ^ T * Phi * V + Delta _ P

para.p: where

Math.text: F * x * (t - tau * t) = (I - Delta _ B * B ^ (- 1) * x) * F * x * (t - tau * t) = (list@(f _ 1, f _ 2, dots, f _ m)) ^ T
F * x * (t - tau * t)
(I - Delta _ B * B ^ (- 1) * x) * F * x * (t - tau * t)
(list@(f _ 1, f _ 2, dots, f _ m)) ^ T

para.p: and

Math.text: Delta _ P = (- Delta _ B * B ^ (- 1) * K ^ T * Phi * V) + (I - Delta _ B * B ^ (- 1)) * (Xi + D)
Delta _ P = (- Delta _ B * B ^ (- 1) * K ^ T * Phi * V) + (I - Delta _ B * B ^ (- 1)) * (Xi + D)

para.p: are column vectors.

p.text: ((7)) Functions b⁢dii and di are continuous unknown. b⁢dii and di respectively satisfy =b⁢dii⁢W⁢BiiTΦ⁢Bii(x) and ≤di⁢W⁢diTΦ⁢di(t) where ∈W⁢BiiRl is unknown bounded constant parameter vectors, ∈⁢Φ⁢Bii(x)Rl is the known continuous smooth bounded regressor vector, ∈W⁢diRl is a vector of unknown bounded constant parameters, and ∈⁢Φ⁢di(t)Rl is a vector of smooth bounded nonlinear function x.
((8)) The unknown continuous functions f1,f2,…,fm satisfy the inequality

Math.text: absolute-value@(f _ i) less= ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ m)@(varrho _ (i * k) * x _ k * (t - tau _ k * t))

p.text: with ϱ⁢ik(xk(t))(i=1,2,…,m) being known positive continuous functions.

((14)) Let ⁢H(s) denote an (×nm)-dimensional exponentially stable transfer function, r be the input and =e⁢H(s)r be the output. Then ∈r⁢L2m⋂L∞m indicates that ∈e,˙e⁢L2n⋂L∞n, e is continuous, and →e0 as →t∞. Moreover, if →r0 as →t∞, then →˙e0.

para.p: Define the filtered tracking error si ((13))

Math.text: s _ i = (e _ i) ^ (n - 1) + lambda _ (i * 1) * (e _ i) ^ (n - 2) + dots + lambda _ (list@(i, n - 1)) * e _ i
s _ i
(e _ i) ^ (n - 1) + lambda _ (i * 1) * (e _ i) ^ (n - 2) + dots + lambda _ (list@(i, n - 1)) * e _ i

para.p: where =ei-yiy⁢di, ei(-n1)(i=1,2,…,m) is the (-n1)th derivative of ei, λ⁢i1,…,λi,-n1 are positive constants and are appropriately chosen coefficient vectors such that →ei0 as →si0 (i.e. +r-m1⁢λ⁢i1r-m2…λi,-n1 is Hurwitz).
From (15), we have

Math.text: dot@(S) = (B _ d) ^ (- 1) * x * delimited-[]@(F * x * (t - tau * t) + K ^ T * Phi * V + Delta _ P) + nu
dot@(S) = (B _ d) ^ (- 1) * x * delimited-[]@(F * x * (t - tau * t) + K ^ T * Phi * V + Delta _ P) + nu

para.p: where =S[s1,…,si,…,sm]T and =ν[ν1,…,νi,…,νm]T with

Math.text: nu _ i = (- (y _ (d * i)) ^ n) + lambda _ (i * 1) * (e _ i) ^ (n - 1) + dots + lambda _ (list@(i, n - 1))

para.p: We now construct a new high dimensional Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional(see Eq. (42)). The first part of the Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional is chosen as

Math.text: V _ 1 = S ^ T * B _ vartheta * S
V _ 1 = S ^ T * B _ vartheta * S

para.p: where

Math.text: B _ vartheta = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * B _ alpha * differential-d@(vartheta)) = diag * delimited-[]@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * B _ (alpha * i * i) * (bar@(x)) _ i * differential-d@(vartheta)))

B _ vartheta = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * B _ alpha * differential-d@(vartheta)) = diag * delimited-[]@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * B _ (alpha * i * i) * (bar@(x)) _ i * differential-d@(vartheta)))

para.p: with Bα=⁢Bdα=⁢diag[⁢b⁢diiα⁢ii]×mm and matrix ∈αR×mm.

For easy analysis, we choose α11=…=α⁢mm. By exchanging x⁢ni in x with ϑsi+ζi(i=1,2,…,m), we define ¯xi=[x1T,x2T,…,x-n1T,x⁢n1,x⁢n2,…,+⁢ϑsiζi,…,x⁢nm]T∈R⁢nm where =ζi-y⁢di(-n1)ξi with =ξi+⁢λ⁢i1ei(-n2)…⁢λi,-n1ei. ϑ is a scalar and independent of ¯xi. We can choose suitable ⁢Bd(x) and α, such that >⁢b⁢diiα⁢ii0.

p.text: We propose Bϑ, which is a diagonal matrix, on the basis of weighted control Lyapunov function (WCLF) defined in (Ge, Hang, Zhang (1999)). The diagonal element of Bϑ is defined as ∫01⁢ϑB⁢αii(¯xi)dϑ. By introducing (19), we construct (18) as the first part of the novel high dimensional Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional. Equation (18) is positive definite in the filtered error S and grows unbounded as →∥S∥∞.

para.p: Because Bϑ in (18) depends on time t, the time derivative of V1 includes the differentiation of matrix Bϑ with regard to time t. To facilitate computation of its derivative, according to ((18)), we introduce a matrix operator for derivative operation of matrix-value function with respect to time t, i.e., for a time-dependent matrix ∈AR×mn and a vector ∈⁢b(t)Rl, a matrix operator ∈⁢M∂(A,b)R×mn is defined with the entry of its ith row and jth column being =⁢M∂⁢ij(A,b)⁢∂A⁢ij∂bT˙b with =i1,2,…,m and =j1,2,…,n.
Differentiating (18) with respect to t gives

Math.text: (dot@(V)) _ 1 = 2 * S ^ T * B _ vartheta * dot@(S) + S ^ T * M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, S) * S + S ^ T * M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, x) * S + S ^ T * M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, zeta) * S
2 * S ^ T * B _ vartheta * dot@(S) + S ^ T * M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, S) * S
+ S ^ T * M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, x) * S + S ^ T * M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, zeta) * S

para.p: where =ζ[ζ1,ζ2,…,ζm]T, ∈⁢M∂(Bϑ,S)R×mm, ∈⁢M∂(Bϑ,x)R×mm and ∈⁢M∂(Bϑ,ζ)R×mm are given below

Math.text: M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, S) = diag * delimited-[]@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(s _ i)) * (dot@(s)) _ i * differential-d@(vartheta)))

M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, S) = diag * delimited-[]@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(s _ i)) * (dot@(s)) _ i * differential-d@(vartheta)))

M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, x) = diag * delimited-[]@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * ((sum _ (formulae@(j = 1, j not-equals i))) ^ (n * m))@((partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(x _ j)) * (dot@(x)) _ j * d * vartheta)))

M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, x) = diag * delimited-[]@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * ((sum _ (formulae@(j = 1, j not-equals i))) ^ (n * m))@((partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(x _ j)) * (dot@(x)) _ j * d * vartheta)))

formulae@(M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, zeta) = diag * delimited-[]@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(zeta _ i)) * (dot@(zeta)) _ i * differential-d@(vartheta))), i = list@(1, dots, m))

formulae@(M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, zeta) = diag * delimited-[]@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(zeta _ i)) * (dot@(zeta)) _ i * differential-d@(vartheta))), i = list@(1, dots, m))

para.p: Let σ=ϑsi(i=1,2,…,m), we can obtain

Math.text: partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(s _ i) = (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(sigma)) * (partial-differential@(sigma) / partial-differential@(s _ i)) = vartheta * (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(sigma))
partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(s _ i)

(partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(sigma)) * (partial-differential@(sigma) / partial-differential@(s _ i)) = vartheta * (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(sigma))

partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(vartheta) = (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(sigma)) * (partial-differential@(sigma) / partial-differential@(vartheta)) = (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(sigma)) * s _ i
partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(vartheta)

(partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(sigma)) * (partial-differential@(sigma) / partial-differential@(vartheta)) = (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(sigma)) * s _ i

para.p: Noting that ϑ is a scalar and independent of ζi, and the fact ˙ζi=-νi(i=1,2,…,m), we have

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(zeta _ i)) * (dot@(zeta)) _ i * s _ i * differential-d@(vartheta)) = - nu _ i * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(s _ i)) * differential-d@(vartheta))

((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(zeta _ i)) * (dot@(zeta)) _ i * s _ i * differential-d@(vartheta)) = - nu _ i * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * (partial-differential@(B _ (alpha * i * i)) / partial-differential@(s _ i)) * differential-d@(vartheta))

para.p: Motivated by (21)-(26), the following equations can be obtained

Math.text: S ^ T * M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, S) * S = S ^ T * (evaluated-at@(delimited-[]@(vartheta ^ 2 * B _ alpha), 0, 1) - 2 * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * B _ alpha * differential-d@(vartheta))) * dot@(S) = S ^ T * B _ alpha * dot@(S) - 2 * S ^ T * B _ vartheta * dot@(S)
S ^ T * M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, S) * S
S ^ T * (evaluated-at@(delimited-[]@(vartheta ^ 2 * B _ alpha), 0, 1) - 2 * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * B _ alpha * differential-d@(vartheta))) * dot@(S)
S ^ T * B _ alpha * dot@(S) - 2 * S ^ T * B _ vartheta * dot@(S)

S ^ T * M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, zeta) * S = S ^ T * (- ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * (partial-differential@(B _ alpha) / partial-differential@(vartheta)) * differential-d@(vartheta))) * nu = (- S ^ T * B _ alpha * nu) + S ^ T * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(B _ alpha * nu * differential-d@(vartheta))
S ^ T * M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, zeta) * S
S ^ T * (- ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * (partial-differential@(B _ alpha) / partial-differential@(vartheta)) * differential-d@(vartheta))) * nu
(- S ^ T * B _ alpha * nu) + S ^ T * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(B _ alpha * nu * differential-d@(vartheta))

para.p: By using the two equations above, we can rewrite (20) as

Math.text: (dot@(V)) _ 1 = (S ^ T * B _ alpha * dot@(S) - S ^ T * B _ alpha * nu) + S ^ T * delimited-[]@(M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, x) * S + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(B _ alpha * nu * differential-d@(vartheta)))
S ^ T * B _ alpha * dot@(S) - S ^ T * B _ alpha * nu
+ S ^ T * delimited-[]@(M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, x) * S + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(B _ alpha * nu * differential-d@(vartheta)))

para.p: Using (16), we have

Math.text: (dot@(V)) _ 1 = S ^ T * B _ alpha * (B _ d) ^ (- 1) * x * delimited-[]@(F * x * (t - tau * t) + K ^ T * Phi * V + Delta _ P) + S ^ T * delimited-[]@(M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, x) * S + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(B _ alpha * nu * differential-d@(vartheta)))
S ^ T * B _ alpha * (B _ d) ^ (- 1) * x * delimited-[]@(F * x * (t - tau * t) + K ^ T * Phi * V + Delta _ P)
+ S ^ T * delimited-[]@(M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, x) * S + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(B _ alpha * nu * differential-d@(vartheta)))

para.p: Since matrices Bd, α and ⁢Bdα are symmetric,we have

Math.text: B _ alpha * (B _ d) ^ (- 1) * x = B _ d * x * alpha * (B _ d) ^ (- 1) * x = alpha

para.p: Then, equation (30) could be rewritten as

Math.text: (dot@(V)) _ 1 = S ^ T * alpha * delimited-[]@(F * x * (t - tau * t) + K ^ T * Phi * V + Delta _ P) + S ^ T * delimited-[]@(M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, x) * S + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(B _ alpha * nu * differential-d@(vartheta)))
S ^ T * alpha * delimited-[]@(F * x * (t - tau * t) + K ^ T * Phi * V + Delta _ P)
+ S ^ T * delimited-[]@(M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(B _ vartheta, x) * S + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(B _ alpha * nu * differential-d@(vartheta)))

para.p: From Assumption 2.3, we can rewrite (32) as

Math.text: (dot@(V)) _ 1 = S ^ T * alpha * delimited-[]@(F * x * (t - tau * t) + W ^ T * Psi + K ^ T * Phi * V + Delta _ P)
(dot@(V)) _ 1 = S ^ T * alpha * delimited-[]@(F * x * (t - tau * t) + W ^ T * Psi + K ^ T * Phi * V + Delta _ P)

para.p: where =z[xT,¯xT,ST,vT]T, =W⁢diag[W⁢Bii], =ΦB⁢diag[Φ⁢Bii] and

Math.text: Psi * z = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(vartheta * M _ partial-differential * open-interval@(Phi _ B, x) * S * differential-d@(vartheta)) + ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(Phi _ B * nu * differential-d@(vartheta))

para.p: Then, given Assumption 2.4 and Lemma 2.1 in ((12)), it is easy to rewrite (33) as follows

Math.text: (dot@(V)) _ 1 = S ^ T * alpha * delimited-[]@(W ^ T * Psi * z + K ^ T * Phi * V + Delta _ P) + S ^ T * alpha * F * x * (t - tau * t) less= S ^ T * alpha * delimited-[]@(W ^ T * Psi * z + K ^ T * Phi * V) + norm@(S ^ T * alpha) * (gamma _ 1 + gamma _ 2 * norm@(V)) + (m / 2) * (norm@(S ^ T * alpha)) ^ 2 + (1 / 2) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ m)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ m)@((varrho _ (j * k)) ^ 2 * x _ k * (t - tau _ k * t)))
S ^ T * alpha * delimited-[]@(W ^ T * Psi * z + K ^ T * Phi * V + Delta _ P)
+ S ^ T * alpha * F * x * (t - tau * t)
S ^ T * alpha * delimited-[]@(W ^ T * Psi * z + K ^ T * Phi * V) + norm@(S ^ T * alpha) * (gamma _ 1 + gamma _ 2 * norm@(V))

p.text: According to Remarks 2.1 and 2.2, we can obtain that the bounded matrix ⁢B(x) is either uniformly symmetric positive definite or uniformly symmetric negative definite for all ∈xRn. Then the inverse ⁢B-1(x) and unknown matrix ΔB should also be bounded. According to Assumptions 2.1 and Assumptions 2.3, Ξ, K and the disturbance vector ⁢D(t) are bounded. Therefore, the vectors ⁢(-I⁢ΔBB-1(x))Ξ, ⁢(-I⁢ΔBB-1(x))D(t) and matrix ⁢ΔBB-1(x) are bounded. As a result, there exist two positive parameters γ1 and γ2 such that

Math.text: norm@((I - Delta _ B * B ^ (- 1) * x) * (Xi + D * t)) less= gamma _ 1
norm@((I - Delta _ B * B ^ (- 1) * x) * (Xi + D * t)) less= gamma _ 1
norm@(- Delta _ B * B ^ (- 1) * x * K * Phi * V) less= gamma _ 2 * norm@(V)
norm@(- Delta _ B * B ^ (- 1) * x * K * Phi * V) less= gamma _ 2 * norm@(V)

p.text: Similar to literatures ((12)) and ((17)), γ1 and γ2 are regarded as robust parameters in controller (36). In practice, we can constantly adjust the two parameters until the proposed controller can stabilize the closed loop system.

para.p: It is easy to check that ⁢Ψ(z) is well-defined even if S approaches zero. We design an adaptive control

Math.text: V = Lambda _ (s * g * n) * u _ 1 + u _ 2
V = Lambda _ (s * g * n) * u _ 1 + u _ 2
u _ 2 = - (beta _ 0) ^ (- 1) * (S / norm@(S)) * rho
u _ 2 = - (beta _ 0) ^ (- 1) * (S / norm@(S)) * rho
rho = cases@(Array[[(gamma _ 1 + gamma _ 2 * norm@(u _ 1)) / (1 - gamma _ 2 * norm@((beta _ 0) ^ (- 1))), [if], S not-equals 0], [0, [if], S = 0]])
rho = cases@(Array[[(gamma _ 1 + gamma _ 2 * norm@(u _ 1)) / (1 - gamma _ 2 * norm@((beta _ 0) ^ (- 1))), [if], S not-equals 0], [0, [if], S = 0]])

para.p: Since ⁢KTΦ≥β0>0, when ≠S0, we can obtain

Math.text: S ^ T * alpha * K ^ T * Phi * V less= - S ^ T * alpha * (K _ 1 + (m / 2) * alpha) * S - (S _ [|⋅|]) ^ T * alpha * (((hat@(W)) _ [|⋅|]) ^ T * Psi _ [|⋅|] * z + Upsilon _ [|⋅|]) - norm@(alpha * S) * rho less= - S ^ T * alpha * (K _ 1 + (m / 2) * alpha) * S - S ^ T * alpha * ((hat@(W)) ^ T * Psi * z + Upsilon) - norm@(alpha * S) * rho
S ^ T * alpha * K ^ T * Phi * V

para.p: where we use the following facts

Math.text: - (S _ [|⋅|]) ^ T * alpha * ((hat@(W)) _ [|⋅|]) ^ T * Psi _ [|⋅|] * z less= - S ^ T * alpha * hat@(W) * Psi
- (S _ [|⋅|]) ^ T * alpha * ((hat@(W)) _ [|⋅|]) ^ T * Psi _ [|⋅|] * z less= - S ^ T * alpha * hat@(W) * Psi
- (S _ [|⋅|]) ^ T * alpha * Upsilon _ [|⋅|] less= - S ^ T * alpha * Upsilon
- (S _ [|⋅|]) ^ T * alpha * Upsilon _ [|⋅|] less= - S ^ T * alpha * Upsilon

para.p: Since ≤∥V∥+∥u1∥∥u2∥, we have ≤-⁢∥⁢STα∥(+γ1⁢γ2∥V∥)⁢∥⁢αS∥ρ0.
Substituting (40) into (35) and noting that ≤∥V∥+∥u1∥∥u2∥ give

Math.text: (dot@(V)) _ 1 less= (- S ^ T * alpha * K _ 1 * S - S ^ T * alpha * (tilde@(W)) ^ T * Psi * z - S ^ T * alpha * Upsilon) + (1 / 2) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ m)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ m)@((varrho _ (j * k)) ^ 2 * x _ k * (t - tau _ k * t)))
- S ^ T * alpha * K _ 1 * S - S ^ T * alpha * (tilde@(W)) ^ T * Psi * z - S ^ T * alpha * Upsilon

para.p: Consider the following Lyapunov function candidate as

Math.text: V _ a

para.p: where =~Wi-Wi^Wi.
The adaption law is designed as

Math.text: dot@((hat@(W)) _ i) = Omega _ i * Psi _ i * z * alpha _ (i * i) * s _ i

para.p: where Ωi>0(i=1,2,…,m) is a diagonal constant matrix to be designed.
⁢VUj(t) is introduced to overcome unknown time-delays ⁢τ1(t),⁢τ2(t),…,⁢τm(t) and defined as

Math.text: V _ U _ j * t = (1 / (2 * (1 - (bar@(tau)) _ (m * a * x)))) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ m)@(((integral _ (t - tau _ k * t)) ^ t)@((varrho _ (j * k)) ^ 2 * x _ k * tau * differential-d@(tau)))
V _ U _ j * t = (1 / (2 * (1 - (bar@(tau)) _ (m * a * x)))) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ m)@(((integral _ (t - tau _ k * t)) ^ t)@((varrho _ (j * k)) ^ 2 * x _ k * tau * differential-d@(tau)))

para.p: From the definition of Va, we have

Math.text: (dot@(V)) _ a = ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ m)@(((tilde@(W)) _ i) ^ T * (Omega _ i) ^ (- 1) * dot@((tilde@(W)) _ i))

para.p: The time derivative of ⁢VUj(t) is

Math.text: (dot@(V)) _ U _ j * t = (1 / (2 * (1 - (bar@(tau)) _ (m * a * x)))) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ m)@(delimited-[]@((varrho _ (j * k)) ^ 2 * x _ k * t - (varrho _ (j * k)) ^ 2 * x _ k * (t - tau _ k * t) * (1 - (dot@(tau)) _ k * t)))
(dot@(V)) _ U _ j * t

para.p: Thus, the time derivative of V2 is

Math.text: S ^ T * alpha * (- K _ 1 * S - Upsilon)

para.p: where =Υ[Υ1,…,Υi,…,Υm]T with

Math.text: Upsilon _ i = (1 / (2 * (1 - (bar@(tau)) _ (m * a * x)) * s _ i * alpha _ (i * i))) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ m)@((varrho _ (i * k)) ^ 2 * x _ k * t)

para.p: Noting that if Υ is utilized to construct the control law, controller singularity may occur, since ⁢(⁢2(-1¯τ⁢max)siα⁢ii)-1∑=k1m⁢ϱ⁢ik2(⁢xk(t)) is not well-defined at =si0. Therefore, define Υi as follows:

Math.text: Upsilon _ i = cases@(Array[[(1 / (2 * (1 - (bar@(tau)) _ (m * a * x)) * s _ i * alpha _ i)) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ m)@((varrho _ (i * k)) ^ 2 * x _ k * t), [if], s _ i not-equals 0], [0, [if], s _ i = 0.]])

para.p: Then, when ≠si0,

Math.text: (dot@(V)) _ 2 less= - S ^ T * alpha * K _ 1 * S less= 0.

para.p: To this end, our main result can be summarized as:

p.text: For the closed-loop system (1) and (36), under Assumptions 2.1-2.4, for bounded initial conditions, the tracking error e1 converges to zero, and the overall closed-loop control system is globally stable in the sense that all of the signals in the closed-loop system are globally bounded.

From Lemma 2.1, it is obtained that the equation =S0 defines a time-varying hyperplan in Rn on which the tracking error e1 converges to zero asymptotically. On the basis of this conclusion, we can obtain that e1 converges to the origin if S converges to zero asymptotically.
In practice, to prevent chattering phenomena, ⁢sgn function in (38) should be replaced by sat function, i.e.,

Math.text: sat * open-interval@(S, epsilon _ s) = cases@(Array[[S / epsilon _ s, [if], norm@(S) less= epsilon _ s], [S / norm@(S), [if], norm@(S) > epsilon _ s]])
sat * open-interval@(S, epsilon _ s) = cases@(Array[[S / epsilon _ s, [if], norm@(S) less= epsilon _ s], [S / norm@(S), [if], norm@(S) > epsilon _ s]])

p.text: where ϵs is a small constant.

para.p: To validate the proposed method, we consider the following 2-DOF robotic manipulator system

Math.text: cases@(Array[[(dot@(x)) _ 1 = x _ 2, ], [(dot@(x)) _ 2 = (B _ d) ^ (- 1) * x * delimited-[]@(F * x * (t - tau * t) + D * t + K ^ T * Phi * V), ], [y = x _ 1, ]])
cases@(Array[[(dot@(x)) _ 1 = x _ 2, ], [(dot@(x)) _ 2 = (B _ d) ^ (- 1) * x * delimited-[]@(F * x * (t - tau * t) + D * t + K ^ T * Phi * V), ], [y = x _ 1, ]])

para.p: We choose robot parameters as =m16 kg, =m23 kg, =l10.8 m, =l20.4 m and =g9.81 /ms2 for numerical simulation. We consider the desired trajectory =yd[sint,cost]T and set the initial conditions =⁢q(0)[0.3,0.5]T and =⁢˙q(0)[0,0]T. We choose =⁢^W1(0)-0.1 and =⁢^W2(0)1 as the initial value of adaption law. The design parameters of the above controller are =λ1110, =λ215, =γ17.2, =γ20.2, =Ω10.02, =Ω20.1, =K1⁢diag[10,5], =β0⁢diag[0.3,1.1], =α⁢diag[14,14] and =ϵs0.2. The parameters of the dead-zone are given as =⁢g⁢ir(vi)⁢k⁢ir(-vib⁢ir) and =⁢g⁢il(vi)⁢k⁢il(-vib⁢il) with the parameters of the dead-zones =k⁢1l0.5,=k⁢1r1.5,=k⁢2l1.5,=k⁢2r2.5,=b⁢1l-0.5,=b⁢1r0.5,=b⁢2l-2.5 and =b⁢2r2. The time-varying delays =⁢τ1(t)⁢0.2(+1.1sint),=⁢τ2(t)-1⁢0.5cost and =¯τ⁢max0.6.

The tracking errors between the joint positions and their references are shown in Figs. 1–2. The time histories of the adaptive parameters are shown in Fig. 3. These three figures show good transient performances the proposed method achieves.

To show the advantages of the proposed method, we choose the conventional PD control and the adaptive neural control proposed in ((9)) for comparisons under the same time-varying delays and unknown dead-zones. As a traditional control method, the PD control can be written as =V--⁢Kpe⁢Kd˙e. In the comparison simulation study, Kp and Kd are respectively set to =Kp⁢diag[45,35] and =Kd⁢diag[10,10]. For the adaptive neural control proposed in ((9)),we also use two 3-layer neural networks containing 10 hidden nodes to approximate the unknown functions as done in ((9)). The controller parameters are chosen as γ10=γ20=3.5, cs1=cs2=0.1, =λ117.5, =λ215, =k113, =k213.2, k13=k23=0.02, =η10.15, =η20.2, ρ1=ρ2=2, σ1=σ2=0.01, σ⁢w1=σ⁢w2=0.1, σ⁢v1=σ⁢v2=0.01, Γ⁢w1=Γ⁢w2=⁢diag{2.5}, Γ⁢v1=Γ⁢v2=⁢diag{15} and =¯τmax0.6.

The comparative simulation results are shown in Figs. 1–2 and Figs. 4–5. From Figs. 1–2, we can see that the PD method cannot make the tracking errors converge. From Figs. 4–5, the control signals of the adaptive neural control proposed in ((9)) can cause chattering phenomenon, which in practice can degrade system performances. From the simulation results, our method can have better performances. Moreover, we construct the controller mathematically by using the adaptive technique to deal with the uncertainty of the considered system, instead of using neural networks approximation as in ((9)) and ((8)). Furthermore, the method of ((8)) lies in the backstepping technique which needs to construct n controllers in the n steps while our method only needs one step in the sense of backstepping.

In order to investigate the control performances of the proposed method under different controller parameters, we also choose different parameters in the simulation. Specifically, we select three pairs of different values of λ11 and λ21, i.e., case 1: =λ1110, =λ215, case 2: =λ115, =λ212.5, case 3: =λ112.5, =λ211.25, to observe how these two parameters affect the control performances. Figs. 6–7 and Figs. 8–9 show the tracking error trajectories and controller output trajectories under different controller parameters, respectively. From these figures, we can observe that the greater the values of λ11 and λ21 are, the faster the convergence rate of tracking errors is, but accordingly the larger the control signals are at the beginning of =t0.

In this paper, an adaptive control method is proposed for a class of uncertain MIMO nonlinear time-varying delay systems with unknown nonlinear dead-zones. The design is based on the use of a new high dimensional integral functional as a Lyapunov-Krasovskii function of the closed-loop systems, with the advantages of global stability and convergence of the tracking errors to origin.
